communications.subject: Texas Public Information Act Request: Untitled
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Texas Public Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Autopsy report for Carla Renee Chapel whose death occurred May 25 2015 in Grand Prairie, Tx.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Tiffanie Chapel

title: Public Records Request: ALPR Log

communications.subject: Indiana Access to Public Records Act Request: Public Records Request: ALPR Log
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Indiana Access to Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

An audit log of all ALPR queries to out-of-state law enforcement agencies between 1/1/2023 and 2/6/2024. This request is not seeking the plate numbers or any personally identifiable information. It is seeking the date and time for conducting a query in the specific date range cited.

A copy of agency policies regarding ALPR queries to out-of-state law enforcement agencies.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 7 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

e

communications.subject: California Public Records Act Request: Flock Installs (Orange County Sheriff's Office)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

Hello, 

I am requesting records related to the installation, approval, and locations of automatic license plate readers from Motorola and Flock Safety

Emails from: 
Akeia Dixon - installs@flocksafety.com
Dave@flocksafety.com
garrett@flocksafety.com
Motorola email domain names

Do not include promo emails or emails from hello@flocksafety.com

Communications related to installations. 
Keyword search: 
"installations"
"install" 
"technicians"
"public works"
"rebates"

Copies of attachments. 
Copies of documentation of installations that include their locations, approvals by the city for installations, and contracts related to the installations 

Limit search to: 2018 - 2023

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Joey Scott

title: CDC monitoring efforts

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: CDC monitoring efforts
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Any reports, maps, memos or emails that directly refer or report on CDC's efforts to monitor human subjects who have had suspected exposure to H5N1 influenza. This request seeks records produced since March 1, 2024. This request seeks records in the possession of the following CDC officials: Daniel Jernigan, Demetre Daskalakis, Dylan George, Kate Wolff, Nirav Shah, Mandy Cohen, and/or Debra Houry. 

I am a reporter for The Nation and other outlets.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Jimmy Tobias

title: West Springfield PD School Based Arrest

communications.subject: Massachusetts Public Records Law Request: West Springfield PD School Based Arrest
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Massachusetts Public Records Law, I hereby request the following records:

To whoever it may concern: 
 
This letter constitutes a request pursuant to the Public Records Act, M. G. L.c.66, §10, for public records in the custody of your police department.
Under the Criminal Justice Reform Act, school districts and law enforcement agencies must “specify the manner and division of responsibility for collecting and reporting the school-based arrests, citations and court referrals of students to the Department of Elementary and Secondary Education” (DESE). DESE began collecting data on school-related arrests in the 2018-19 school year. In the 2019-20 school year, DESE has expanded that collection to include data on all referrals to law enforcement. DESE has defined these terms as follows, borrowing the same definitions used by the U.S. Department of Education since its 2009 Civil Rights Data Collection. 
A school-related arrest “[r]efers to an arrest of a student for any activity conducted on school grounds, during off campus school activities (including while taking school transportation), or due to a referral by any school official. All school-related arrests are considered referrals to law enforcement.” 
A referral to law enforcement “[i]s an action by which a student is reported to any law enforcement agency or official, including a school police unit, for an incident that occurs on school grounds, during school-related events, or while taking school transportation, regardless of whether official action is taken. Citations, tickets, court referrals, and school-related arrests are considered referrals to law enforcement.” 
 
I request the following public records, as defined in M. G. L.c. 4, § 7 (twenty-sixth): 
 
1. An extract of your records management system or database that includes each school-related arrest and each referral to law enforcement conducted during the 2018-2019, 2019-2020, 2020-2021, 2021-2022, and 2022-2023 school year (up until the day the records are produced). Specifically, we request an extract of the database to include the following columns: 
a. Date of arrest or referral to law enforcement 
b. Time of arrest or referral to law enforcement 
c. Charge (or charges) 
d. Whether the individual(s) was arrested or referred to law enforcement 
e. Sex of individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement 
f. Age of individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement 
g. Race of individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement 
h. Ethnicity of individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement 
i. Disability status of the individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement 
j. Whether the individual arrested or referred to law enforcement is a student at the school.
k. Name of arresting officer, if applicable, and 
l. Badge number of the arresting officer or the officer that referred the youth to law enforcement, as applicable. 
 
2. If such an extract of the database in question 1 is not possible, please provide police reports and school incident reports on each school-related arrest conducted during the 2018-2019, 2019-2020, 2020-2021, 2021-2022, and 2022-2023 school year (up until the day the records are produced). 
 
3. Please provide an unduplicated count of arrested students for each school year including 2018-2019, 2019-2020, 2020-2021, 2021-2022, and 2022-2023 school year (up until the day the records are produced). 
 
4. If such an extract of the database in question 1 is not possible, please provide police reports and school incident reports on each referral to law enforcement conducted during the 2018-2019, 2019-2020, 2020-2021, 2021-2022, and 2022-2023 school year (up until the day the records are produced), per the U.S. Department of Education’s Civil Rights Data Collection for that year. For each referral to law enforcement, please include the school, demographic, and incident information described in DESE’s School Safety and Discipline Report Data Handbook v. 20.0. 
 
5. Please also provide an unduplicated counts of referrals to law enforcement (as defined above) for each school year including 2018-2019, 2019-2020, 2020-2021, 2021-2022 and 2022-2023 school year (up until the day the records are produced).  
As this request involves a matter of public interest and will not be used for any commercial purpose, we ask that all fees associated with this request be waived pursuant to 950 C.M.R. 32.07(2)(k). The purpose of this request is to determine whether your school district and police department are complying with their reporting obligations under the Criminal Justice Reform Act. “The public has an interest in knowing whether public servants are carrying out their duties in an efficient and law-abiding manner.” 
 
It would be ill-advised to impose a fee for data that your police department may have failed to report in violation of statutory and regulatory duty. Moreover, as you know, municipalities with a population of over 20,000 may not assess a fee for the first 2 hours of time spent searching for, compiling, segregating, redacting and reproducing a requested record. Finally, pursuant to 950 C.M.R. 32.07(2)(i), a records access officer shall assess no fee greater than the lowest hourly rate of a person capable of compiling, segregating, redacting and reproducing a requested record. In the event that a charge is incurred for this request which you will not waive, please so indicate and include an itemization of estimated good faith costs. 
Please provide public records to a requestor in an electronic format unless the record is not available in an electronic format. M. G. L.c 66, § 6A(d). 
The Public Records Act requires that you comply with this request within ten (10) business days following receipt. If you believe that documents or data responsive to any request herein is not public record and thus not subject to disclosure, please set forth in writing the specific reasons for such assertion, including the specific exemption or exemptions that you believe apply. To the extent that you determine that records need to be redacted in order to be produced under any law protecting the privacy of named individuals, please do so rather than withholding them in their entirety.
If you have any questions about this request, or need additional time to respond, please contact me. Thank you in advance for your prompt response to this request. 
 
Sincerely, 
Rylee Meints
J.D. Candidate
Research Assistant
Center for Public Interest, Advocacy, and Collaboration 
meints.r@northeastern.edu

I also request that, if appropriate, fees be waived as we believe this request is in the public interest, as suggested but not stipulated by the recommendations of the Massachusetts Supervisor of Public Records. The requested documents will be made available to the general public free of charge as part of the public information service at MuckRock.com, and is not made for commercial usage.

I expect the request to be filled in an accessible format, including for screen readers, which provide text-to-speech for persons unable to read print. Files that are not accessible to screen readers include, for example, .pdf image files as well as physical documents.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Rylee Meints

Your request for information from the New Mexico Educational Retirement Board was forwarded to me. In accordance with the New Mexico Inspection of Public Records Act (IPRA), “a written request shall provide the name, address and telephone number of the person seeking access to the records and shall identify the records sought with reasonable particularity.” Section 14-2-8(C) NMSA 1978.


If you will provide me with your name and mailing address, we can begin the process of allowing inspection of the relevant records.


The Inspection of Public Records Act can be found at 14-2-1 through 14-2-12 NMSA 1978.

Amanda Olsen

communications.subject: RE: New Mexico Inspection of Public Records Act Request: Water Asset Management funds correspondence
communications.communication:
Dear Ms. Rock,

I am responding to your email yesterday requesting any additional info regarding the source of delays on this request. Please be assured that we make every effort to respond promptly to every request. However, we must also ensure that we are diligent and accurate in our reply. Thus, when obtained, all documents and emails must be reviewed. Additionally, we must rely on the state agency that controls the entire state email system to identify and provide the emails requested. As you can imagine, the process takes time.

As to an estimated response date, in our letter of August 1, 2023, we noted that we intend to respond by September 6, 2023.

Thank you for your patience and please feel free to contact me if you have further questions.

Respectfully,

communications.communication:
Dear Ms. Rock and Ms. Burns,

Thank you for your inquiry and please accept our apologies for the delay.

As Mr. Scroggins noted in his August 3, 2023 email regarding our projected response, we always try to be prompt.  But as you might guess, the request references a large number of records.  As he said, we must thoroughly review all records to identify and obtain the responsive documents from both external and internal sources.  It is a complex and time-consuming process.

I am confident that we will have documents ready to provide on or before the December 6th, 2023, date noted in our recent communication.

Thank you for your continued patience!
Regards,
Renee

communications.communication:
Thank you so much for your assistance, Renee. I was able to download the documents via the server instructions you provided. I look forward to your response on or before February 1st for the remaining documents.

Have a wonderful holiday season!

communications.subject: Re: Request for Inspection of Records
communications.communication:
Ms. Rock and Ms. Burns:

Attached is additional correspondence regarding your June 16, 2023 request.

Thank you,


[Jennifer Jaques  Paralegal/Legal Assistant  Jennifer.Jacques@erb.nm.gov]

title: Child care provider data (Oklahoma Department of Human Services)

communications.subject: Oklahoma Open Records Act Request: Child care provider data (Oklahoma Department of Human Services)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Oklahoma Open Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

Historical data on all licensed child care providers (active and closed) from as far back as data systems will allow to present. I also request data on license-exempt providers, if available. Specifically, I request the following information as it is available:

1)	Provider name or ID
2)	Street number
3)	Street name
4)	City
5)	Zip code
6)	Licensed capacity for each year (by child age group if available)
7)	Enrollment for each year (by child age group if available)
8)	Provider type (e.g., center-based provider, home-based provider, Head Start, school-based pre-K, etc.) for each year
9)	First license issue (open) date
10)	Most recent license issue date
11)	Most recent license expiration date or close date
12)	Ages served for each year
13)	Hours of operation for each year
14)	QRIS rating for each year (please explain who is required to participate and whether there are financial supports based on rating)
15)	Accepts Child Care and Development Fund subsidies for each year
16)	Accepts other types of subsidies for each year (please list types)
17)	Prices for each year (by child age group if available)
18)	Violation records

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days.

Sincerely,

Gabrielle Pepin

communications.subject: RE: Oklahoma Open Records Act Request: Child care provider data (Oklahoma Department of Human Services)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

I wanted to follow up on the following Oklahoma Open Records Act request, copied below, and originally submitted on Feb. 13, 2025. Please let me know when I can expect to receive a response.

Thanks for your help, and let me know if further clarification is needed.

communications.subject: Re: [EXTERNAL] RE: Oklahoma Open Records Act Request: Child care provider data (Oklahoma Department of Human Services)
communications.communication:
This request was received.  Efforts are underway to determine if responsive records are in the possession, custody, or control of the Department.
Thank you,
Ron Baze

Get Outlook for iOS<https://aka.ms/o0ukef>

communications.subject: RE: [EXTERNAL] Oklahoma Open Records Act Request: Child care provider data (Oklahoma Department of Human Services)
communications.communication:
In response to the Oklahoma Open Records Act request below that was submitted to the Oklahoma Department of Human Services, the Department conducted a good faith search to determine if any records exist that are in the possession, custody, or control of the Department and is maintained in the ordinary course of business.  Specifically, your request sought records associated with 18 data points maintained by the Child Care Licensing Division of the Department.  As a consequence of that search, the Department submits the following in response to each of those data points contained in your request:

  1.  Provider name or ID - please see attached record
  2.  Street number - please see attached record
  3.  Street name - please see attached record
  4.  City - please see attached record
  5.  Zip code - please see attached record
  6.  Licensed capacity for each year (by child age group if available) - please see attached record
  7.  Enrollment for each year (by child age group if available) - data is maintained in a format that is accessible to the public, specifically the Department's child care locator portal
  8.  Provider type (e.g., center-based provider, home-based provider, Head Start, school-based pre-K, etc.) for each year - please see attached record
  9.  First license issue (open) date - This data is not maintained neither in a readily accessible format by the Department nor in the ordinary course of business.  Production of the requested data would require a manual search of each individual facility record and would be unduly burdensome on the Department.
  10. Most recent license issue date - please see attached record
  11. Most recent license expiration date or close date - Once obtained by a facility, licenses renew each year and do not naturally expire.   Consequently, the requested data is neither captured nor maintained by the Department in the ordinary course of business
  12. Ages served for each year - data is maintained in a format that is accessible to the public, specifically the Department's child care locator portal
  13. Hours of operation for each year - data is maintained in a format that is accessible to the public, specifically the Department's child care locator portal
  14. QRIS rating for each year (please explain who is required to participate and whether there are financial supports based on rating) - please see attached record
  15. Accepts Child Care and Development Fund subsidies for each year - please see attached record
  16. Accepts other types of subsidies for each year (please list types) - please see attached record
  17. Prices for each year (by child age group if available) - Data is not captured or maintained by the Department in the ordinary course of business
  18.  Violation records - data is maintained in a format that is accessible to the public, specifically the Department's child care locator portal
It is believed the responses provided above fully address your submitted request. Consequently, the Department will consider this request closed.

Thank you,
Ron E. Baze
General Counsel
Oklahoma Department of Human Services
(405) 818-9836

title: SHORELINE SCHOOL DISTRICT - JLARC (2024) Agency Costs Fulfilling Public Records Requests Including Litigation for the year 2024

communications.subject: Washington Public Records Act Request: SHORELINE SCHOOL DISTRICT - JLARC (2024) Agency Costs Fulfilling Public Records Requests Including Litigation for the year 2024
communications.communication:
January 12, 2025

via email to  via email to public.records@ssd412.org

SHORELINE SCHOOL DISTRICT - JLARC (2024) Agency Costs Fulfilling Public Records Requests Including Litigation for the year 2024
 
To whom it may concern,

RCW 40.14.026(5)

“To improve best practices for dissemination of public records, each agency with actual staff and legal costs associated with fulfilling public records requests of at least one hundred thousand dollars during the prior fiscal year must… report to the joint legislative audit and review committee by July 1st of each subsequent year the following metrics, measured over the preceding year:

RCW 40.14.026(5)(l)

(l) The estimated costs incurred by the agency in fulfilling records requests, including costs for staff compensation and legal review, and a measure of the average cost per request;

RCW 40.14.026(5)(o)

(o) The costs incurred by the agency with managing and retaining records, including staff compensation and purchases of equipment, hardware, software, and services to manage and retain public records or otherwise assist in the fulfillment of public records requests;

PUBLIC RECORDS REQUEST RCW 42.56

Pursuant to the Washington Public Records Act [RCW 42.56] I hereby request the following records:

1. Please provide all "Public Records" (as defined by WAC 44-14-03001) detailing costs incurred by your agency in fulfilling records requests, including staff compensation, legal review, and any public records related litigation costs and/or legal settlements for the year 2024 and complete copies of all records request realted fee payments paid to your agency in 2024.

Responsive public records should include but are not limited to:

Supplies and services external services (e.g., printing services, large format printing) Mailing costs, supplies (CDs, DVDs, USB sticks, etc.) Staff compensation and benefit records, copies of payments of Public Records Fees Collected, Software licensing, public records portal and database software licensing and costs, purchases of equipment, hardware, software, and services to manage and retain public records or otherwise assist in the fulfillment of public records requests, professional services Agency staff costs, copies of billing for all Legal costs – including copies of all litigation Legal settlements related to public records requests litigation of any kind and copies of costs for staff time associated with invoicing and collection.

RECORDS INSTALLMENTS

If production of responsive records will be completed in multiple installments, please begin by producing records in the numerical order requested by subject matter and year. The most recent public records should be produced first.

DEFINITION OF RECORDS AND WRITINGS

RECORDS AND WRITINGS as defined by RCW 42.56.010(4): any handwriting, typewriting, printing, photostating, photographing, and every other means of recording any form of communication or representation including, but not limited to, letters, words, pictures, sounds, or symbols, or combination thereof, and all papers, maps, magnetic or paper tapes, photographic films and prints, motion picture, film and video recordings, magnetic or punched cards, discs, drums, diskettes, sound recordings, and other documents including existing data compilations from which information may be obtained or translated.

PRODUCTION AND DELIVERY OF ELECTRONIC RECORDS

Please provide all records in their native electronic format. Please do not instead create new records by printing electronic files then scanning and printing the newly scanned prints.

The use of 3rd party “portals” (Such as GOVQA or NEXTREQUEST) for communication and production of records in response to a public records request is optional for the requestor in the State of Washington. Respectfully we decline to use any 3rd party "portal" system, specifically GOVQA and NEXTREQUEST. Please provide all records electronically via direct email attachment, or via no password, no registration internet cloud-based download link.

Please do not direct or invite us to use, register for, or communicate with your agency via any 3rd party portal including but not limited to FOIAOnline, GovQA, NextRequest, FOIAExpress, JustFOIA FOIADirect, WebForm, or any other commercial 3rd party records portal service.

Constructive Notice: Any and all communication(s) received on behalf of your agency in reference to this Public Records Request (RCW 42.45) from any unauthorized for-profit 3rd party company doing business outside the State of Washington will be the subject of a new public records request to your agency as to the origin and purpose of the communication as well as the identity of the sender of the communication.

PUBLIC RECORDS REQUESTS SUBMITTED VIA EMAIL

RCW 42.56.080 - Identifiable records—Facilities for copying—Availability of public records.

"...Agencies shall honor requests received in person during an agency's normal office hours, or by mail or email, for identifiable public records unless exempted by provisions of this chapter. No official format is required for making a records request; however, agencies may recommend that requestors submit requests using an agency provided form or web page."

This public records request is being made via email. This public records request will be honored and fulfilled by your agency via email as requested or relief will be sought per statute.

NATIVE ELECTRONIC FORMAT

Please provide all identified public records in their NATIVE electronic format. Unless the records exist IN PAPER FORM ONLY, DO NOT instead create new records by printing native stored electronic files, then scanning and re-printing these newly scanned prints only to reproduce them in again in electronic production.

EMAIL RECORDS

Please provide any and all email records in NATIVE .pst electronic format.

FEES

In the event that there are fees, please inform us of the total charges in advance of fulfilling the request in strict compliance with all provisions of the Washington State Public Records Act.

EXEMPTION - FAMILY EDUCATIONAL RIGHTS AND PRIVACY ACT (FERPA)

Take caution with the broad application of redaction and withholding of identified public records claiming "global FERPA" exemptions. When an agency claims an exemption for an entire record or portion of one, it must inform the requestor of the statutory exemption and provide a brief explanation of how the exemption applies to the record or portion withheld. RCW 42.17.310(4)/42.56.210(3). The brief explanation should cite the statute the agency claims grant an exemption from disclosure. The brief explanation should provide enough information for a requestor to make a threshold determination of whether the claimed exemption is proper. Global, nonspecific claims of exemption such as "FERPA" are insufficient. One way to properly provide a brief explanation of the withheld record or redaction is for the agency to provide a withholding index. It identifies the type of record, its date and number of pages, and the author or recipient of the record (unless their identity is exempt). The withholding index should allow a requestor to make a threshold determination of whether the agency has properly invoked the exemption. There are several exceptions to the FERPA exemption and any agency silently withholding large swaths of public records citing "FERPA!" without providing the original identified record, properly redacted, or if withheld in its entirety, providing a record description and page count or record length, will be challenged in accordance with RCW 42.56.550 if a reasonably detailed withholding index or exemption log is not included.

EXEMPTION LOGS

Please ensure all redactions or exemptions claimed by your agency in the production of responsive records are accompanied by a complete and detailed exemption log noting the valid legal reason for each exemption at each redaction location in the record produced, as well as the specific number of pages if any that your agency redacts or withholds in their entirety. Each redaction should be noted by footnote or by a clear reference to the specific justification for that redaction, and only the minimal exempt portion of any record may be withheld.

COMMERCIAL PURPOSE DECLARATION

The Washington State Public Records Act prohibits the disclosure of “lists of individuals” for a commercial purpose (RCW 42.56.070(8)). I declare this public records request is not being made for any commercial purpose whatsoever. Also, this public records request is not being made for a "list of individuals." This declaration satisfies all requirements of RCW 42.56 regarding prohibitions on lists and commercial purposes. No additional commercial purpose declaration will be completed for this public records request.

COMMUNICATION VIA EMAIL

Please send all requests for clarification, status updates, and production of responsive electronic documents via direct email.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. We look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Good Luck.

communications.subject: 25-10 Re: Washington Public Records Act Request: SHORELINE SCHOOL DISTRICT - JLARC (2024) Agency Costs Fulfilling Public Records Requests Including Litigation for the year 2024
communications.communication:
Hello,

This is Shoreline School District with acknowledgment of your public
records request received January 13, 2025.

As authorized by RCW 425.56.520, the District will require additional time
to respond to your request for the purposes of locating and assembling the
information requested, notifying affected parties related to this request,
and determining if any of the information requested is exempt under
Washington or federal law. At this time, the District anticipates it will
have records prepared for you on or before February 28, 2025.

The District has various fees for different types of records produced. You
may review our fee schedule beginning on page 8:
https://app.eduportal.com/documents/view/886377.

We will notify you when an installment of records is available. If you have
not paid for and inspected the records within 30 days of the installment being
made available, the District reserves the right to close the request.

Thank you.
*Shoreline School District*
Public Records Requests
<https://www.ssd412.org/about-us/public-information-records-transcripts/public-records-requests>

communications.subject: Re: Washington Public Records Act Request: SHORELINE SCHOOL DISTRICT - JLARC (2024) Agency Costs Fulfilling Public Records Requests Including Litigation for the year 2024
communications.communication:
Good morning,

This is Shoreline School District with response to your request for public
records received January 13, 2025, requesting:



*…**all "Public Records" (as defined by WAC 44-14-03001) detailing costs
incurred by your agency in fulfilling records requests, including staff
compensation, legal review, and any public records related litigation costs
and/or legal settlements for the year 2024 and complete copies of all
records request related fee payments paid to your agency in 2024.*

Attached you will find invoices from legal counsel which includes legal
costs regarding public records for 2024..  There were no public records
settlements in 2024.

The District utilizes NextRequest Software, 2024 invoices are attached.

Attached are reports of records request fee payments paid to the District
in 2024.

No specific supplies were purchased for public records in 2024.

There is no responsive record specific to invoicing or staff costs
associated with public records.

Because the cost of producing the enclosed documents is less than $2.00,
charges have been waived.



If you find this in error, please respond to this email at your earliest
convenience.



This request is closed.


*Shoreline School District*
Public Records Requests
<https://www.ssd412.org/about-us/public-information-records-transcripts/public-records-requests>

title: November 1, 2024 Accident Report

communications.subject: DC Freedom of Information Act Request: November 1, 2024 Accident Report
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the DC Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

A copy of the PD-10 Accident Report OR any other publicly releasable records related to a bicycle-vehicle collision that occurred on the evening of November 1, 2024, at approximately 7:00 PM, at the intersection of Constitution Ave NW and 3rd Street NW in Washington, D.C (near 301 Constitution Ave). The CCN number for this accident is 24170107. I was present at the scene and, while not directly involved, I am seeking information and a narrative description on the incident to understand what occurred and to confirm the condition of the cyclist who was struck and the severity of the crash. communications.subject: Public Records Request :: R007913-022625
communications.communication:
Dear Patrik Szigeti: 
Thank you for your interest in public records of District of Columbia. Your request has been received and is being processed. Your request was received in this office on 2/26/2025 and given the reference number R007913-022625 for tracking purposes. 
In all future correspondence regarding this request, please reference request number R007913-022625. You can monitor the progress of your request in the " My Records Center". 
 
The District of Columbia is required to respond to your FOIA request within fifteen (15) business days of its receipt.  See D.C. Official Code § 2-532(c)(2011).  However, under certain circumstances, D.C. Official Code § 2-532(d)(2011) authorizes the District to extend, by ten (10) additional days, the deadline by which it must respond to a FOIA request.  One of the circumstances provided by that statute is a case in which the District needs additional time to search for, collect and examine voluminous amounts of records and/or consult with an additional D.C. agency. 
For any questions regarding your request, please contact the FOIA office directly. Find the list of agency Open Government and FOIA contact information by visiting FOIA Contact Information. For ease of reference, we ask that you have your FOIA Reference Number available when you contact the FOIA office. 
Regards, 
District of Columbia

title: US Army support for 2023 film "My Christmas Hero"

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: US Army support for 2023 film "My Christmas Hero"
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Any documents pertaining to collaboration between the US Army and the production of the 2023 movie "My Christmas Hero," directed by Martin Wood and starring Candace Cameron Bure. I request any and all documents pertaining to Army support for "My Christmas Hero." Such documents may include but should not be limited to: script notes; production assistance agreements; and all records of communications between employees of the Army and members of the cast, crew, and production company of "My Christmas Hero," including memos, notes of meetings and conference calls, emails, and other forms of communication.

At least one entertainment media outlet reports that "the production team specifically utilized the premise of the Joint Base Lewis–McChord, which is situated near the city of Lakewood in Pierce County, to shoot scenes set at the Joint Military Base in Lacey, Washington. the production" (TheCinemaholic, Nov. 23, 2023, https://thecinemaholic.com/where-my-christmas-hero-filmed-cast/).

I am the Director of Research Operations at a 501(c)(3) non-profit organization called The Decoding Culture Foundation. These documents will be used for public education and research purposes. I therefore request a waiver of all fees that may otherwise apply. Attached is a document with organization letterhead confirming my position, as well as the organization's 501(c)(3) application and approval form.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Brett Carollo

Please be advised that this office has no records, it only serves as the referral point and policy office for the Department of the Army Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) Program. Requests for information and documents under the purview of the Army is referred to the proponent agency for appropriate handling in accordance with Army Regulation 25-55, The Army Freedom of Information Act Program. Your FOIA request has been assigned the following case number: FA-24-1773 / FP-24-015543.

The correct office to process your request is the Office of the Chief of Public Affairs FOIA Office.  We have copied their office and are referring your request to them, by way of this email, for processing and direct response to you. Please note that once it is received in their office it will be assigned a new FOIA case number. Their contact information has also been provided below for your convenience.

To Whom It May Concern:

I wanted to follow up on the following Freedom of Information Act request, copied below, and originally submitted on April 8, 2024. Please let me know when I can expect to receive a response.  You had assigned it reference number #FA-24-0056.

Thanks for your help, and let me know if further clarification is needed.

communications.subject: RE: Freedom of Information Act Request #FA-24-0056
communications.communication:
To whom may it concern,

Good afternoon, you are addressing the wrong FOIA office. Records Mgmt & Declassification is not our office, we are Chief Attorney and Legal Services. The Army’s FOIA program is extremely decentralized and various offices/address can be similar. With that said, please be advise we have just been made aware of an administrative error pertaining to one of our sub activities. You should have received a no records response for your “civil war” FOIA request and not “My Christmas Hero” as previously sent to you on 11JUL2024. Please see updated letter in this attachment.  We sincerely apologies for the lack of oversight. The FOIA request  for “My Christmas Hero” is still pending awaiting on responsive records/review. You will be getting a response once the findings make it to this office level for review as the Initial Denial Authority (IDA). Many thanks and have a good weekend.





Very Respectfully





Freedom of Information Act Office (FOIA)|

Office of the Administrative Assistant to the Secretary of the Army (OAA)|

Chief Attorney and Legal Services (CALS)|

title: Request for Body Cam Footage of Incident Involving Alexandria 09/18/2022

communications.subject: Florida Sunshine Law Request: Request for Body Cam Footage of Incident Involving Alexandria 09/18/2022
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Florida Sunshine Law, I hereby request the following records:

I am writing to formally request access to the bodycam footage under the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) related to the arrest of a woman identified as Alexandria on 09/18/2022.

Incident Details for Footage Retrieval:
Date: 09/18/2022
Location: Maitland, Florida
Suspect: Alexandria
Incident Summary: Alexandria was involved in a dispute with her father regarding transportation. When officers arrived, they attempted to reason with her, explaining that her father was not obligated to drive her. Despite multiple requests to exit the vehicle, Alexandria refused and was eventually removed from the car and placed under arrest. During the encounter, she made allegations against the officers and resisted arrest before being taken into custody.

I am requesting copies of all body-worn camera footage from officers who responded to this incident.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days.

Sincerely,

Harun

title: NoHo Diagnostic Center

communications.subject: California Public Records Act Request: NoHo Diagnostic Center
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

I am writing to formally request records related to a Los Angeles Police Department raid that took place in October 2023 at the NoHo Diagnostic Center, located in the Van Nuys neighborhood of Los Angeles. Specifically, I am requesting the following records:

1. Body camera footage: Any and all body-worn camera footage recorded by LAPD officers during the raid on the NoHo Diagnostic Center, including any video prior to, during, and after the incident where an officer’s rifle was attracted to an MRI machine.
   
2. Incident Reports: Any official incident or field reports prepared by LAPD officers regarding the raid at the NoHo Diagnostic Center, including any documentation of the circumstances surrounding the raid, property damage, and the involvement of LAPD officers.

3. Communications: Any and all communications (emails, text messages, memos, etc.) between LAPD officers, supervisors, and/or other relevant officials regarding the planning, execution, or aftermath of the raid on the NoHo Diagnostic Center. This includes any communications referencing cannabis cultivation, energy usage monitoring, and the distinct odor cited in the lawsuit.

4.  Internal Investigation Records: Any records related to internal reviews or investigations conducted by the LAPD into the actions taken by officers during this raid, including the incident involving the MRI machine and any other property damage claims.

5. Photographs: Any photographs taken by LAPD officers or forensic units at the scene of the NoHo Diagnostic Center during or following the raid.

If any portion of these records is exempt from disclosure, I request that you release any segregable, non-exempt portions of the records. Please do not withhold the entire set of records if certain parts are subject to exemption, in accordance with public records laws.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Dhruv Mehrotra

communications.subject: [External Message Added] City of Los Angeles public records request #24-10814
communications.communication:
City of Los Angeles ************************************************************************ A message was sent to you regarding record request #24-10814: Dear Requester,   We have received your request for various records related to the incident that occurred in October 2023 at the North Hollywood Diagnostic Center.   Your request was made under the California Public Records Act (the Act). The Department is cognizant of its responsibilities under the Act. It recognizes the statutory scheme was enacted to maximize citizen access to the workings of government. The Act does not mandate disclosure of all documents within the government’s possession. Rather, by specific exemption and reference to other statutes, the Act recognizes that there are boundaries where the public’s right to access must be balanced against such weighty considerations as the right of privacy, a right of constitutional dimension under California Constitution, Article 1, Section 1. The law also exempts from disclosure records that are privileged or confidential or otherwise exempt under either express provisions of the Act or pursuant to applicable federal or state law, per California Government Code Sections 7927.200; 7927.700; 7923.600-7923.625; 7927.705; and 7922.000. Regarding requested item No. 1,2,4, and 5, in accordance with Sections 7923.600-7923.625 of the California Government Code, records of investigations conducted by, or investigatory files compiled by, any local police agency for law enforcement purposes, are exempt from disclosure. To the extent that records were located, they are either investigatory records themselves or properly part of an investigative file. Therefore, we are denying your request. The records may be provided pursuant to a subpoena or court order related to pending litigation. For Requested item No.3: Regarding text messages, please also note that currently the Department has over 11,600 employees, thus we are unable to conduct a search for text messages based on the information provided. If you wish to proceed with this item, please provide additional information (name, serial numbers, date range etc.), to assist with the search. Please respond by no later than October 28, 2024. If we do not receive a response by the date indicated, we will consider this item closed. Regarding email communications, please note that our office—the LAPD Public Records and Subpoena Response Section, CPRA Unit—does not house the records you are seeking. The Department is in the process of searching for the requested records. Please note that some of the records to be provided may be redacted pursuant to California Government Code Sections 7927.200; 7927.700; 7923.600-7923.625; 7927.705; and 7922.000. We will make every effort to produce the requested records by November 18, 2024 and will notify you should anything change.    If you have any questions, please respond to this email.   Respectfully,   LAPD Public Records & Subpoena Response Section, CPRA Unit ************************************************************************ Questions about your request? Reply to this email or sign in to contact staff at City of Los Angeles.
Technical support: See our help page

We will provide you with an update by December 16, 2024, if not sooner. Respectfully,   LAPD Public Records & Subpoena Response Section, CPRA Unit ************************************************************************ Questions about your request? communications.subject: Your City of Los Angeles public records request #24-10814 has been closed.
communications.communication:
City of Los Angeles ************************************************************************ Record request #24-10814 has been closed. The closure reason supplied was: Dear Requester, Thank you for your patience. Regarding Item No.3, the Department has completed its review and provided you with responsive, non-exempted records. Your request was made under the California Public Records Act (the Act). The Department is cognizant of its responsibilities under the Act. It recognizes the statutory scheme was enacted to maximize citizen access to the workings of government. The Act does not mandate disclosure of all documents within the government’s possession. Rather, by specific exemption and reference to other statutes, the Act recognizes that there are boundaries where the public’s right to access must be balanced against such weighty considerations as the right of privacy, a right of constitutional dimension under California Constitution, Article 1, Section 1. The law also exempts from disclosure records that are privileged or confidential or otherwise exempt under either express provisions of the Act or pursuant to applicable federal or state law, per California Government Code Sections 7927.200; 7927.700; 7923.600-7923.625; 7927.705; and 7922.000. In accordance with the California Government Code, Section 7923.600, records of investigations conducted by, or investigatory files compiled by, any local police agency for law enforcement purposes are exempt from disclosure. Therefore, records that contain investigatory records or records properly part of investigative files are being provided to you with redactions or withheld. Additionally, records were withheld pursuant to Section 7927.700. This includes “personnel, medical or similar files, the disclosure of which would constitute an unwarranted invasion of personal privacy.” If you have any questions, please respond to this email.   Respectfully,   LAPD Public Records & Subpoena Response Section, CPRA Unit ************************************************************************ Questions about your request? Reply to this email or sign in to contact staff at City of Los Angeles.

communications.subject: California Public Records Act Request: Request for Body-Worn Camera Footage: Jaime Valdez (11/11/2023)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

All unedited body-worn camera / bodycam recordings related to the following law enforcement critical incident:

Incident Date: November 11, 2023

title: ALPR Audits (Fontana Police Department)

communications.subject: California Public Records Act Request: ALPR Audits (Fontana Police Department)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

Part A - Information related to ALPR data sharing.

A1. The names of agencies and organizations with which the Agency shares ALPR data;

A2. The names of agencies and organizations from which the Agency receives ALPR data;

A3. The names of agencies and organizations with which the Agency shares “hot list” information;

A4. The names of agencies and organizations from which the Agency receives “hot list” information.

The information requested in items A1-A4 is readily available for extraction through the ALPR software you use. For example, with Vigilant Solutions/Motorola Solutions, this data can be exported easily using the Data Sharing Report function. With Flock Safety, this information is available through the transparency portal function. Other software, such as BOSS, has similar functionality. 

In a small number of cases, an agency has interpreted items A1-A4 as requesting the creation of a record that does not exist. We disagree: this data is maintained by your software, can be exported through software your agency has already purchased, and is therefore subject to CPRA. 

However, should you disagree, you may alternatively produce the following records: 

A5. All agreements, memoranda of understanding, requests, or other certifying documents that external agencies have signed to comply with Sec 1798.90.52(b) for accessing your agency's ALPR data. These documents are also often required under the "Releasing ALPR Data" subsection of a California law enforcement agency's SB 34 policy. 

A6. All agreements, memoranda of understanding, requests, or other certifying documents your agency has signed under Sec 1798.90.52(b) to access other agencies' ALPR data.

A7. All "records of access" required by Sec. 1798.90.52(a) from 2019 until the date of processing this request. 

Items A5-A7 are unnecessary if your agency provides the information requested in items A1-A4. We feel that items A1-A4 are more focused and would require less labor from your agency to produce. 

Part B - Information Related to Numbers of “Detections” (plate scans) and “Hits” (plate scans that matched to a hotlist)

B1. The aggregate number of "detections" collected 2019 to today's date

B2. The aggregate number of “hits” 2019 to today's date

The information requested in items B1-B4 is readily available through the ALPR software you use. For example, with Vigilant Solutions/Motorola Solutions, this data can be exported easily using the Hit Ratio Report function. With Flock Safety, this information is available through the transparency portal function. Other software, such as BOSS, has similar functionality. As noted above, this information exists within your system and can be easily exported with existing software.


Records of: 
- Officers with authorized access to ALPR systems
- Any audits that include records for the reason of the search, misuse, and how many times the ALPR search was run. 
- The number of times other agencies, including federal agencies, with access to the department's ALPR data.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Joey Scott

title: Request for Body Cam Footage of DUI Arrest on March 20, 2024

communications.subject: Maryland Public Information Act Request: Request for Body Cam Footage of DUI Arrest on March 20, 2024
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Maryland Public Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Incident Details for Footage Retrieval:

Date: March 20, 2024
Location: Montgomery County, Maryland
Suspect: Karen Huger, 61
Incident Summary: Huger was arrested for DUI after crashing her Maserati into a median and two signs. Reports indicate she was highly intoxicated, appeared incoherent, and made unusual statements to officers on scene. Bodycam footage from her arrest was later released, showing her referring to herself as "Thomas Jefferson's concubine" and claiming she was "extremely intelligent." She was charged with DUI, DWI, and reckless driving.
I am requesting copies of all body-worn camera footage from officers who:

Responded to the scene of Huger’s crash.
Conducted any field sobriety tests or questioning.
Placed her under arrest and transported her to detention.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Harun

title: Request for Body Cam Footage of Arrest on October 30, 2024

communications.subject: Georgia Open Records Act Request: Request for Body Cam Footage of Arrest on October 30, 2024
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Georgia Open Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

Incident Details for Footage Retrieval:

Date: October 30, 2024
Location: Fannin County, Georgia
Suspect: Brittany Patterson, 41
Incident Summary: Patterson was arrested at her home and charged with reckless endangerment after her 10-year-old son walked less than a mile into town alone. Bodycam footage captures officers informing Patterson of her arrest at her doorstep, placing her in handcuffs, and escorting her to a police vehicle.
I am requesting copies of all body-worn camera footage from officers who:

Responded to the call regarding Patterson’s son.
Transported the child home.
Arrested Patterson at her residence.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 3 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Harun

title: Contract Awarded to Deloitte for Connecticut Care4Kids Child Care Subsidy System

communications.subject: Connecticut Freedom of Information Act Request: Contract Awarded to Deloitte for Connecticut Care4Kids Child Care Subsidy System
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Connecticut Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Find the request for proposal, statement of work, and all related documentation for the contract Deloitte for child care subsidy system known as Care4Kids (C4K);  Connecticut Office of Early Childhood.

I also request that, if possible and pursuant to Conn. Gen. Stat. § 1-212(d), fees be waived as I believe this request is in the public interest and not made for commercial gain. The requested documents will be made available to the public at MuckRock.com.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 4 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Toni Thompson

communications.subject: FOI Records Request :: R000061-120524
communications.communication:
Dear Toni Thompson: 
 
 
This message is an acknowledgement that the Connecticut Office of Early Childhood received your Freedom of Information Act request on 12/5/2024. It was given the reference number R000061-120524 for tracking purposes. 
 
 
This letter does not constitute a denial of your request. Rather, in accordance with the Freedom of Information Act, we are in the process of researching and gathering documentation which may be responsive to it. Once the documents are gathered, we will then conduct a review to determine if statutory exemptions to disclosure may apply to some or all of the documents. Upon completion of that review, we will be able to provide you with any responsive, non-exempt documents. 
 
Please note the department reserves the right to charge any such other fees as may be appropriate pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act. 
You can monitor the progress of your request at the link below and you'll receive an email when your request has been completed. Again, thank you for using the OEC FOI Records Center. 
Connecticut Office of Early Childhood

title: Body Camera Footage of Mark Roher’s Arrest (January 18, 2024)

communications.subject: Florida Sunshine Law Request: Body Camera Footage of Mark Roher’s Arrest (January 18, 2024)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Florida Sunshine Law, I hereby request the following records:

I am requesting access to body-worn camera footage related to the January 18, 2024, arrest of Mark Roher at Boca Lago Country Club in Boca Raton, Florida.

Incident Details for Footage Retrieval:
Date: January 18, 2024
Location: Boca Lago Country Club, Boca Raton, FL
Suspect: Mark Stuart Roher (52 years old)
Incident Summary:
Roher was involved in an altercation at a wedding buffet over the prime rib carving station.
He allegedly smashed a plate over another guest’s head after an argument about children skipping the line.
A large brawl ensued, with multiple guests reportedly getting involved.
Roher claimed he was the real victim and insisted that another guest kicked him.
Bodycam footage reportedly captures Roher:
Complaining about being arrested and stating: "I want to press charges against him."
Invoking his right to remain silent but later admitting he initiated the conflict.
Telling deputies: "I don't think it's right that you're parading me in front of them."
Witnesses, including a waiter at the venue, confirmed that Roher struck the victim with a plate.
Roher was charged with aggravated battery with a deadly weapon and later released on $1,000 bond.
His next court date is scheduled for February 20, 2024.
Requested Footage:
Bodycam footage from all officers who:
Responded to the scene at Boca Lago Country Club.
Interacted with or arrested Mark Roher.
Recorded Roher’s statements regarding the incident.
Transported Roher to jail or processed him at the station.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days.

Sincerely,

Harun

title: Request for Body Cam Footage of Arrest on January 24, 2025

communications.subject: Florida Sunshine Law Request: Request for Body Cam Footage of Arrest on January 24, 2025
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Florida Sunshine Law, I hereby request the following records:

Incident Details for Footage Retrieval:

Date: January 24, 2025
Location: Bonita Springs, FL
Suspect: Sabrina Deanna Coyne, 34
Incident Summary: Deputies responded to a residence in Bonita Springs after a homeowner was awakened by a loud crash and banging on the front door. Surveillance footage allegedly showed Coyne throwing a brick—engraved with "first date" and the couple’s names—through the home’s window. When questioned, Coyne denied throwing the object and claimed to live there, but the ex-boyfriend stated she had moved out six months prior. She was arrested and charged with criminal mischief and throwing a deadly missile into an occupied dwelling.
I am requesting copies of all body-worn camera footage from officers who:

Responded to the scene on January 24, 2025
Interacted with Sabrina Deanna Coyne during the investigation.
Took Coyne into custody.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days.

Sincerely,

Harun

title: Ebrahim Yazdi, Sadeq Qotbzadeh, and Mostafa Chamran

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Ebrahim Yazdi, Sadeq Qotbzadeh, and Mostafa Chamran
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Any documents about or mentioning Iranian-American politician Ebrahim Yazdi (26 September 1931 – 27 August 2017). His death is widely-known and widely reported, including by the U.S. government's own Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty (https://www.rferl.org/a/ebrahim-yazdi-iran-ayatollah-dissident-revolution-shah-dies/28699708.html). As such, privacy concerns under FOIA Exemptions 6 and 7 are voided, as are any concerns under the Privacy Act. 

Any documents about or mentioning Iranian-American politician Sadeq Qotbzadeh, also spelled Sadegh Ghotbzadeh (24 February 1936 – 15 September 1982). He also went by the alias "Sadegh Asfahani." His death is widely-known and widely reported, and was even the subject of a February 2020 documentary by BBC Persian; as such, privacy concerns under FOIA Exemptions 6 and 7 are voided, as are any concerns under the Privacy Act. 

Any documents about or mentioning Iranian-American politician Mostafa Chamran Save'ei (2 October 1932 – 21 June 1981). His death is widely-known and widely reported; as such, privacy concerns under FOIA Exemptions 6 and 7 are voided, as are any concerns under the Privacy Act. See the following article on Chamran's posthumous biography: https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/sep/01/iran-widows-memoirs-iran-iraq-war

Yazdi immigrated to the United States in 1961. became a naturalized US citizen in Houston in 1971. Qotbzadeh came to the United States in 1959, and attended Georgetown University's Walsh School of Foreign Service from 1959 to 1963. Chamran moved to the United States in the late 1950s for higher education. He was hired in by NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory in the 1960s, according to the 2010 book "Let the Swords Encircle Me: Iran — A Journey Behind the Headlines" by Scott Peterson.

Qotbzadeh, Yazdi, and Chamran, became close aides to the Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, who was then in exile in Paris, in 1978. They all participated in the overthrow of the Iranian government and the establishment of the Islamic Republic of Iran.

Yazdi was elected to the parliament of Iran from 1980 to 1984. (His U.S. citizenship had been revoked by then.) He fell out of grace with the Islamic Republic and was barred from running for office in subsequent elections. Yazdi was arrested on unknown charges in December 1997 and several times again in 2009 and 2020.

Qotbzadeh served as foreign minister of Iran in 1980, but was purged and executed in 1982.

Chamran served as deputy prime minister, defense minister, and Irregular Warfare Headquarters chief in the new government. He was killed during the Iran-Iraq War on 21 June 1981.

If any part of these documents are exempt from disclosure, please be sure to review and release all reasonably segregable nonexempt portions of responsive documents, as the FOIA requires.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Matthew Petti

communications.subject: RE: Freedom of Information Act Request #COW2023004112
communications.communication:
To whom this may concern,

I am writing in response to my 11 June 2023 request (control number COW2023004120) for documents on Sadegh Ghotbzadeh. The agency wrote back on 15 June 2023 stating that "We have completed a search of all USCIS databases based on your request. No records responsive to your request were located."

I am appealing this determination on grounds that the search was not thorough enough, and am requesting another search that includes alien files created by the Immigration and Naturalization Service.

The National Archives also wrote to me in a 15 June 2023 letter (see attached) that "If someone immigrated to the U.S. after April 1944, they will have what is known as an alien file (or “A” file), which would contain a record of your alien number and a copy of their naturalization certificate. This file remains in the legal custody of the U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS) Agency until 100 years after their date of birth."

Documents previously released by the FBI (see attached) indicate that Ghotbzadeh resided in the United States as a legal alien, that the Immigration and Naturalization Service was given information on Ghotbzadeh, and that INS commissioner Raymond F. Farrell personally spoke to Ghotbzadeh about his case on at least one occasion. As I mentioned in my initial request letter, Ghotbzadeh's name may also be spelled "Sadeq Qotbzadeh," and is given as "Sadegh Asfahani" in some documents.

I look forward to hearing your response within twenty working-days, as the statute requires, and I thank you for your cooperation on this matter.

Best regards,
Matthew Petti

communications.subject: Get Your USCIS Immigration Records Faster, Online
communications.communication:
Get Your USCIS Immigration Records Faster, Online   (https://first.uscis.gov/favicon.ico)  
 
 Hello, 
 You recently requested information from us under the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA),
                and you already have a USCIS online account. 
 In response to COVID-19, we must temporarily reduce our capacity for processing paper FOIA requests and delivering records by mail. 
 We strongly recommend that you https://first.uscis.gov to receive a faster response and to help keep our workforce safe. (https://first.uscis.gov) 
Step 1: Find Your Request in Your Online Account 
  
  * Login to your USCIS online account using this link: https://first.uscis.gov (https://first.uscis.gov) 
  * After you login, click the "View My Requests" button. 
  * A message will appear, asking if you have a new request to register. Click "Yes". 
  * Enter the FOIA control number and PIN we mailed to you and click the "Register Case" button. 
  * Success! You will see your request on the "My Requests" page in your account. 
 
Step 2: Use the My Requests Page 
  
  * Now you can check the My Requests page to see the status of your request. 
  * We will notify you by email to check this page when the information you requested is ready. 
  * Once we post the information here, you can view or download anytime. 
 
 Thanks for helping us provide you with a more efficient service! 
 USCIS 
If you have troubles logging into your account, please call the USCIS Contact Center toll-free at 800-375-5283. 
For people who are deaf, hard of hearing or have a speech disability: TTY 800-767-1833. 

THIS RESPONSE HAS BEEN AUTO GENERATED. PLEASE DO NOT REPLY TO THIS MESSAGE.
